title: Male Yeast Infections
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: What Is a Male Yeast Infection?
content: A male yeast infection is an infection of the area around your penis and testicles caused by an overgrowth of a common fungus we all have on our skin. You usually hear about women having yeast infections, or what doctors call candidiasis . But  men can get them, too. In men, yeast infections are also sometimes called penile yeast infection, candida balanitis, or balanitis thrush (a yeast infection in the throat).

sections.heading: Male Yeast Infection Causes and Risk Factors
content: Candida albicans is a common fungus . You’ve probably got a small amount living in your mouth , digestive tract, or on moist parts of your skin . Women often have some in their vagina . Most of the time, candida doesn’t cause any problems. But if too much of it grows in one place, you get a yeast infection.

You could get this inside your mouth (doctors call this oral thrush ) or as a skin infection. Men can also get a yeast infection on the tip of their penis . This leads to balanitis . It’s more common in men who aren’t circumcised and have a foreskin that’s still intact. If this infection makes it hard for you to pee, seek medical help right away.

sections.heading: Male Yeast Infection Symptoms
content: If you have a yeast infection on your penis, you could have:
In serious cases, you may have a hard time peeing or keeping control of your urine stream.
bullets: Itching or burning on the tip of your penis or the foreskin
Redness
A moist feeling on the tip of your penis
Discharge that looks like cottage cheese and might have a bread-like or unpleasant smell
Swelling around the tip of your penis and foreskin
Sores or white patches of skin
Trouble pulling back your foreskin
A hard time getting or keeping an erection

sections.heading: Male Yeast Infection Diagnosis
content: Your doctor will ask about your symptoms and check your penis for signs of a yeast infection. If needed, they may use a swab to take a sample from the tip of your penis to send to a lab for testing.  Since many STDs share some of the symptoms of a yeast infection, you shouldn’t try to diagnose yourself.

sections.heading: Male Yeast Infection Treatment and Home Remedies
content: Your doctor may suggest:
If you keep having yeast infections and aren’t circumcised, your doctor may suggest circumcision, especially if your foreskin is very tight (a condition called phimosis).
You can help clear up your infection by:
bullets: An over-the-counter antifungal cream or prescribe one to get rid of the infection
A steroid cream such as hydrocortisone
An oral medication called fluconazole
Cleaning and drying your penis well, including pulling back the foreskin to wash and dry the skin beneath it
Managing your diabetes if you have it
Losing weight if you are obese
Avoiding any soaps or other chemicals that cause irritation

sections.heading: Male Yeast Infection Complications
content: If your immune system is weak, there’s a chance that the fungus can spread into your bloodstream. This is a serious condition called invasive candidiasis. Though it is rare, the odds are higher when you:
A high fever , chills, upset stomach , and headache are all signs that your yeast infection may have spread. If you notice these symptoms, call your doctor right away.
bullets: Have HIV
Have diabetes
Are having chemotherapy or radiation
Need dialysis
Are taking immunosuppressants ( drugs that quiet your immune system)
Have a central venous catheter (a tube in your chest that’s used to give you medicine)

sections.heading: Male Yeast Infection Outlook
content: You should be feeling better and the infection should be gone within 3 to 5 days of starting treatment. If you are not, or if your symptoms come back, talk to your doctor.

sections.heading: Male Yeast Infection Prevention
content: The best way to stop a yeast infection from happening (or coming back) is to practice good hygiene, including:
bullets: Cleaning and drying your penis each time you shower and after sex
Choosing unscented soaps and skin products
Wearing a condom during sex when your partner has a yeast infection
Wearing loose cotton underwear to prevent moisture from building up under your foreskin
